We are deeply saddened by the events that took place in Kenosha, WI this weekend that has left Jacob Blake fighting for his life. It’s a harsh reminder that our nation has so much more work to do. Our thoughts and prayers go out to the Blake family.

Six months in to this pandemic we want to acknowledge the all-too-clear changes we are all seeing and experiencing in our own city. Philadelphia has seen gun violence at levels we haven’t seen in over a decade. Our heart breaks for our community and especially the young people being affected by these escalations in violence.

Our children deserve safe neighborhoods, they deserve the chance to reach their highest potential. We are here for you and can help with working through the anxiety and stress during this time. Our support services hotline number is (267) 990-8284. Please call us if you have any needs and we will get you the right support. #blacklivesmatter

📸 : Billy Penn

As we prepare our education plans for the coming school year, we are beginning our student onsite testing next week.

Why do we conduct on-site testing? This testing is important to help us evaluate and then meet each student’s individual needs. We can level set where students are in order to get them the right support, ensuring they are set up for success from the start. On-site testing also provides opportunity for students to meet their teachers in person, easing the transition into virtual learning.

As part of the celebration and in the spirit of #teacherappreciationweek last week, students also submitted heartwarming photos and videos to thank their teachers for all they do. ❤️

We are so grateful for you all and just love our community so much and are excited about the response and to share these photos today!

post_text: Belmont staff member Carter Belmont testified before the school board last night that Belmont Charter School‘s children “deserve better than the environment they have now.” Despite her pleas and the signatures of 900 Belmont community members in favor of Belmont buying the building, the school board pulled the vote on the sale off the table. That means no chance of the new roof, air conditioning or playground we had planned. We’ll keep fighting for Belmont’s children.
